DOC.HEAD: Neighborhood That Was Home To 28,000 Burned To Ground
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks ago hundreds of people gathered around a large TV to watch their neighborhood hero, Roberto Duran, fight American boxer Sugar Ray Leonard and make the kind of money they cannot even dream of. Last week, they watched another fight on the streets of El Chorrillo as the invading Americans attacked Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's headquarters nearby. Many were killed or wounded; thousands lost their homes. On Dec. 7 they sat on the ground to watch the match on a large screen set up on a flatbed truck provided by Gustavo Torreclosa, El Chorrillo's representative to Noriega's rump national legislature. ``Stonehands'' Duran lost, but the people of El Chorrillo were philosophical about it. Leonard dominated the fight, but their El Chorrillo-born hero had held several world championships. He'd had his day. El Chorrillo had 28,000 residents, mostly black and poor. Every Friday night was an outdoor party of music and dancing, with fresh fried fish and beer sold on the sidewalk. The beer was cheap _ it usually ``fell off a truck'' down at the Balboa docks. Petty crime was a danger, and there were plenty of ``maleantes,'' or hoods, and those who tried to act like hoods. The barrio was right next to Noriega's headquarters. Wednesday morning, U.S. cannon fire and swept across the neighborhood for hours as troops moved in to try to capture the general. The general is gone, but so is El Chorrillo. The wooden structures, dating back to the late 1800s and early 1900s, burned like tinder under the shattering cannonade. The fire lit the sky through the night and sent a pall of smoke across the city throughout the next day. Buildings that were home to thousands were reduced to a frieze of charred sticks. Hundreds were wounded and more than a hundred were dead, according to doctors at Santo Tomas Hospital, a mile down the shore. Torreclosa was among the first victims. Everyone who was not wounded or killed left. Many were dazed, many were unable to take out even a single possession. ``We tried to avoid civilian casualties,'' said a U.S. soldier who had been there the night of the attack. He refused to give his name. On Saturday, the area was still off limits. U.S. tanks and soldiers patrolled the streets with loudspeakers warning everyone to stay away. ``Why did they do this?'' a resident asked, looking at the rubble that had been his building 200 yards away. ``Just because they wanted to get Noriega?''
